ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Soriano Mario Jr.
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Marioi Soriano Jr.
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario was very helpful, knowledgeable, and responsive.
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario Soriano
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Soriano, Mario Jr.
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario was always very helpful, and patient with our questions.He also was responsive by email which I appreciated.
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario Soriano

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Availability, willingness to answer questions all great
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  My experience with Mario was limited to test review sessions, but he was an excellent leader of those sessions and provided clear direction and insight.

Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario was great. Though I only attended one study session with Mario, he was very patient, helpful, and explained any course material the group struggled with clearly and thoroughly. Because students have a lot of questions during study sessions, my only suggestion for Mario is to focus on the most important questions and resolve the rest later so that we could touch on all of the material outlined for the session in a timely manner.
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  I think he could have been a bit more supportive if you were struggling to understand a concept
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  The office hours were offered shortly after the pset was assigned which made them not as useful time-wise. Other than that, I have no recommendations.
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  He had a very good understanding of the subject and wide experience
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario knew his stuff and was always willing to help.

Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  I think Mario did a great job! Though I kind of wish that there had been time for more of an open question session for the midterm/ final review, not just a standard 4 to 5 problem worksheet to complete. I just had other questions I needed answered...and the review sessions didn't allow for free-form question-and-answer.

Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  He was very patient and thorough and stayed over time with us during test-prep sessions. He's very good at math and I think sometimes his trigonometric explanations of how to solve complicated word problems scared/off-put some of the class that is a bit weaker in math/more exam oriented.

Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario patiently went through and issues I had with course material. The only thing I wish was a bit different were the marks on the problem sets. Could have used a more thorough explanation of what I actually did wrong and what the correct answers were. That or a corrected key posted to Canvas.
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario was super helpful and responsive. He was a great TA

Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Answers to questions were sometimes vague or unsatisfying. It seemed like better communication between the TA and the professor may be needed since there were some mistakes on the practice problems sometimes that made the review sessions more complicated than necessary.
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario is a specialist in hydrology, sometimes forgetting how a non-hydrologist thinks
Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Excellent in all fronts!

Instructor: Mario Jr. Alipio Soriano  Mario was incredibly patient, which was essential for this challenging course. He throughly explained concepts and would follow up with additional information if needed.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Jim is a fantastic teacher. The concepts are clear and the lectures are engaging. It is a pleasure to be a part of the class. I appreciate all jokes.
Jim's an excellent instructor--clear and responsive to student questions. Can't speak highly enough of the lectures.

I really enjoyed this course and greatly appreciate all of the time the professor put in outside of class, as well as in class, explaining the course material to make sure that it was understood by all students.
Really enjoyed the class and it's balanced mix of concepts and practical applications.

I didn't mind the quantitative aspects of the course but I would have enjoyed hearing a little more about some case studies using the hydrological equations and concepts to help me retain some of the ideas. As someone who will not be a field hydrologist I wonder how much of the course I will retain or find useful in the future. That is not the fault of the course or instructor it is just impossible to teach to students with so many different post graduation objectives.

It's probably worth mentioning that this course isn't that useful for someone who's already been taking courses in water at FES for a year and a half. I think it might be useful to cross check the curriculum with physical sciences, Science to solutions, biogeochemistry and pollution,water resources management and organic pollutants, only because there's quite a bit of overlap. I know the course isn't built for someone necessarily you has a background in water, but maybe that's something that needs to be considered and perhaps an additional course needs to be developed for people that actually specialize in water issues.

Jim Saiers is great! He explains everything very clearly, works students through the complex math without condescension or assumptions, stops and answers questions as necessary, but also keeps the class moving. Crucial class for any environmental managers who might ever deal with water.

The Professor was always available to answer any questions you had. The textbook was not useful to me at all and eventually I stopped using it. A few of the readings helped but not in a significant way.
The course was math heavy, real world application would have been more helpful. Most people are practioners and would benefit more from seeing these concepts applied

The scope of this class was too broad. I was disappointed that there was not a course offered that explored hydrology's interface with riverine and riparian ecosystems and how to manage for the health of those systems in tandem with meeting human needs.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Jim
Lectures and homework assignments.

The lectures were engaging and the class was very organizedI had a good sense of what to expect and how to pace my work accordingly. I enjoyed hearing about the professor's own research as well because it provided a very clear application of some of the more abstract concepts covered. Though we did this more toward the end of the course, I found going through practice problems together as a group very helpful to my understanding of the course material. I also appreciated that the professor continually checked in with the entire group to make sure that everyone understood the material covered and spent more time explaining any content the group found confusing.
Very comfortable atmosphere, where everyone was at ease asking questions, and professor was very reactive to student comments/questions.
Everything was very helpful, clear, and made easy to understand.
Jim's an engaging lecturer who manages to make abstract material engaging.
The teaching was really good and created interest on the subject
The practical cases that were presented by the instructors and other experts in the field.
Jim is an outstanding lecturer especially with quantitative material that could be very challenging to stay engaged with.

I thought the problem sets were an excellent way to practice the problems we discussed in class. In some ways I wish we had more problem sets, or even optional assignments to test our understanding throughout the semester. Like the study assignment for instance was a really great way even though wasn't collected, to really see if we understood the concepts being presented. This is simply because the readings were just not that useful at all and only about 20% of any given chapter was being covered in class.

I think any environmental scientist/manager should understand the way water moves on the surface and subsurface. This class provided exactly that introduction and I'm glad I took it. Jim Saiers is a dynamic, entertaining professor; an hour and 20 minutes of equations goes surprisingly fast when Jim is leading it!
The in-class process of working through the equations and the concepts behind them. Talking about the broader ecological implications of some of the more technical math.
Good exposure to hydrology concepts without being too quantitative. I liked how Saiers had some classes where we focused on applied hydrology topics such as the everglades or fracking.

Jim's dedication to teaching made this class. He clearly cares about his students and is determined to see them succeed. He took extensive time out to explain the course materials to me when I was stuck, and his door is always wide open -- a model I wish more professors at FES would follow. His jovial presentation style made the class engaging and fun. I genuinely looked forward to class, even if some of the material was over my head at first. It is in large part because of Jim's positivity that I was able to push through and feel good about the final and the course material more broadly. As for the course material itself, I really enjoyed the wetlands lecture and the final fracking lecture. I wish there had been more examples of how the material we were learning in class are applied in the real world. Would've given me some context for the math and concepts we learned more regularly.
Jim is a great teacher. I've never had a teacher that made concepts so clear and easy to understand.

I really enjoyed the guest speaker working on the Florida Everglades project, and hearing about the technicalities of fracking in conjunction with Jim's research. It was important for me to occasionally connect the more dense material we were learning to real life examples. The groundwater problem sets were also helpful in conceptualizing the material.
The professor's clear and reasonable manner
1. Lectures are structured and well delivered. 2. Illustrated how materials can be applied in real-world, e.g. Everglades restoration Skype-in and fracking impacts.

The material was so interesting and very relevant for those working in water resources, even those on the policy side. Jim is also a hoot. He is a very engaging professor and clears cares about offering quality instruction to the students. Very learning centric environment.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Students NEED to know stats. Going over basic stats in class was brutal.
Nothing I can think of.

I would have loved to go on several field trips throughout the course. I think this would add a lot of value and likely help students absorb the concepts covered. I found the readings more confusing than helpful. I don't think the textbook is necessary.
The homework due dates overlapping with the midterm was a bit hectic, but that's really it.
I feel that more information could have been covered in this course.

It would be great to build the class around a case study of Dr. Saiers' work on hydrofracking. That way, students would learn the science as well as an applied framework that would show how to use specific skills in context with desired goals and outcomes.
No any i thought off..keep up the good work.
None
Only thing I could think of is perhaps a few more case studies to show how some of the concepts are used in practice. When those were provided, I found them very helpful.

I'd say there were certain periods where we spent a long time uncertain topics that didn't need to be so thorough. I wish we had more time to do some more of the modeling that we did towards the end of the semester. Like use more Matlab and such.

There were a few times this semester when I found the class disrespectful to the professor. I hope it was just a fluke of the time/group/class dynamic and would never occur in a future teaching of the course. Some of the homework assignments this term were frustrating because they required sophisticated use of software (Excel), which wasn't offered/covered/coordinated at the beginning of the course. The most frustrating moments of the semester for me were when I spent hours on homework assignments - not because I didn't understand the hydrological concepts or because I was struggling with equations - but because I couldn't get Excel to log-scale an axis and produce a flow duration curve (H.W. 3). H.W. should test the concepts, not our mastery of the programs! Regarding that, I appreciated Jim walking us through the MatLab assignment; homework 5 was great in exactly that sense: testing the concepts, not proficiency in MatLab, which was cool to use.

I wish there had been another 1-3 classes on water quality and perhaps even management, so that we weren't just talking about quantity and movement. In other words, an overview of the most serious pollutants, where they come from, what effects they have, and how to manage for them based on some of the hydrological principles we'd learned.
none

I wish there had been a field trip associated with this class. I also wish there was a small lab component. Especially in a class and subject area that relies so much math to describe the physical world, seeing that world (or a lab simulation of it!) would have been useful for making the math more tangible and real. The textbook for the course also needs to go. Way too technical, and made things more confusing than clear. Either would like to see a less confusing book, or otherwise supplemental readings that connect the technical material to their application.

Some of the material is really hard to visualize. Some comptuterized models, physical models, or field trips to streams etc. may help supplement the slides. For example dropping dye into a beaker of water to show dispersion. I also felt like the beginning problem sets were tedious and did not contribute to my learning of the material in a significant way.
Application of hydrology to forest systems was missing

1. It would have been better if we had adhered to the schedule of the syllabus and gone through all materials. Almost every class the first 20-30 mins were spent repeating materials from the previous session. As a result we had to drop the last week's topic on watershed analysis. 2. Can we include some Friday field trips, and see how hydrology is actually done on the ground? Could we visit some local reservoirs, groundwater monitoring sites, USGS stream gauge houses, etc.?

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
No lab, please add in the future!

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Required by the MF program. Very interesting stuff... definitely piqued my interest in hydrology
This was a really excellent compliment to the MF program requirements--I felt like we got a great overview and working knowledge.

I'm not sure specifically how I will apply the material covered in the course just yet (time will tell), but the course expanded my general understanding of water systems. I think it is beneficial for anyone interested in water resource management.
This course gave me practical knowledge about hydrology, something I hope to pursue more in the future.
My focus is in Water resource management and hydrology in a pinnacle in the subject
It is a requirement for the MF program and I am extremely glad that it is. Very valuable course to anyone taking a systems-level approach to forestry or conservation.

As someone who wants to pursue a career in water resources management, this course is really important in understanding how water flows through certain systems both on the surface and in the groundwater.
See Q.17
Necessary for my degree
I am interested in aquatic ecology and although I do not want to be a hydrologist, this class provided a solid foundation to my scientific knowledge.
As someone interested in coastal and water policy, and understanding of the physical system is critical. Wish there were more water-related classes at FES, and grateful that Jim taught this course.
It is required for the MF program

This course gives me greater insight into what we can calculate and quantify when it comes to water resources planning. I also learned more about groundwater which is very useful. I may not need to do these calculations on my own in the future but it's good to know what tools there are. As someone focusing in water resources, taking this course also gives me more credibility.

I didn't have much previous experience and knowledge in hydrology. This class made me "scientifically literate" in this hydrology, allowing me to comprehensive most scientific literature in this field and pursue more advanced subjects.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Requirement and I like math
I wanted to better understand hydrology to inform my career working on safe drinking water. I also wanted to overcome my fear of science.
MF curriculum requirement.
I'm interested in understanding water systems and climate adaptation/mitigation in coastal regions.
I am very interested in freshwater systems and groundwater plays a large role in their dynamics.
I took this course to learn more about water and the properties of groundwater.
It fits with my overall career goals
It was required, but I am also very interested in the subject. I am very glad that space was made for this to fulfill a requirement and a personal interest.
I took this course because I really needed some background in hydrology.
To understand how water moves
Necessary for my degree + I wanted a fundamental understanding of hydrological systems.
I wanted to understand hydrology and prepare me for the river restoration class which this class is a prerequisite for.
See question 20
Strongly encouraged for water focused people.
Required
Environmental hydrology is central to my academic and career interests. Fitting and proper to take it at FES during my first year.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Yes. Jim made the material very approachable.
Yes!

Aspects of the course were challenging for me in the beginning, having not taken calculus, but the professor's patience and thorough explanations really helped me grasp all of the material covered throughout the duration of the course.
Yes, they did
Yes and much more
Yes
Yes.

Not exactly. I felt like some of the information was presented in ways that could have been more accelerated. In the year and a half that I've been here, I picked up a lot of the stuff we learned in hydrology already through other courses, and so it felt repetitive at times. Maybe that's a function of the fact that a lot of the students in the course haven't taken a class in water, maybe there's some way to do it differently to meet everyone's expectations.
yes
Absolutely! One of the best courses I took this spring.
Yes- good mix of conceptual and quantitative learning
I honestly didn't expect there to be as much math involved -- I was surprised by that, but am pleased with how I was eventually able to grasp the material.

Yes. This course did a good job of not being too techical for a range of students. This a challenge at our school since we have people with engineering backgrounds and people with more social science oriented backgrounds.
Yes
YES
Yes, I learned quite a bit

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Informally, I completed problem sets with a work group. I found this really helpful. We talked through all of the problems as a small group, making sure that everyone conceptually understood the material. We figured out a strategy for solving problem sets together and then cross-checked our answers. Explaining the content to each other helped everyone in the group grasp the material.
I understood the subject matter much more better

My one group experience was an in-class assignment in which 2-3 groupmates moved way more quickly than I could and I struggled to keep up + I was less interested in the technical issues of the calculations and more interested in seeing the conceptual overview of what we were trying to do, which I had trouble making space for most of that class because of the time pressure.

The two in-class group assignments were mostly dominated by one or two members of the team A lot of time was spent on sheer calculations and not hydrological concepts. In the future in-class group work could be distributed the day before the class, so that all students have time to read through the material and get ready to jump straight into the core of assignment.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Always try the problem sets out on your own first
I would start reviewing the course material early and attend office hours with any questions from the get-go.
Absolutely take this course-it is not very difficult, but you still learn a fair bit.
Its a very well taught and the professor gives practical experiences of work he is currently doing.It is a good course to take for someone who would like to learn the foundations of hydrology
The course provides a good mix of physics concepts, quantitative analyses and environmental applications.

Definitely don't take this course if you have any background in engineering, because it will be way too easy. But, if you don't have a background in that it's a really great course for everything from stream hydrology to groundwater contamination. If you've already taken biogeochemistry and pollution, it may not be as useful.
Take it!
Do the readings; they're not that hard Ask questions in class Take really good notes
Work in a group for the problem sets/homework. You don't need to buy the text book unless you learn well from reading it.

Do not be afraid of the math! It is worthwhile, and if you think of equations as stories, it helps. Go to Jim with any and all questions. This is an intimidating class for folks who are not equation inclined, but I found it to be a really rich and wonderful experience.

Even if you are not a technically minded person I would challenge yourself and take the course. Jim is very patient and very accessible to answer questions. For people focusing in water it's important to have some idea of what we can and can't measure or estimate, and how complicated it can be to do so. This class also builds on some of the physical sciences material related to water.
The professor is excellent at explaining things
If you don't have a strong stats background, this class will be a bit challenging, but do not despair! Jim and the TA are so helpful. Never hesitate to ask them for help.
